modules.description: This module defines a 3D point structure with `x`, `y`, and `z` float coordinates. It provides basic operations such as point creation, coordinate access, and vector arithmetic (addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication). These operations support tasks like 3D plotting, geometric transformations, and OpenGL rendering within the plotting library.

Implements 2D point operations for plotting, including coordinate creation, transformation, and distance calculations. Works with floating-point Cartesian coordinates for precise graphical representation. Used to define plot markers, track mouse positions, and compute geometric relationships in charts.

This module implements low-level rendering and interaction logic for 2D/3D plots, handling OpenGL context setup, coordinate system transformations, and real-time input event processing (mouse/keyboard). It operates on internal representations of geometric primitives (`plot_object`, `gllist`), view state (`view`), and UI flags to enable dynamic plot manipulation, LaTeX-based text rendering, and cross-platform window management. Typical applications include interactive data visualization tools with custom controls, animated scientific simulations, and export pipelines for publication-quality vector graphics.

This module provides functions for constructing and rendering 2D/3D visualizations, including parametric curves, surfaces, animations, and annotated plots, with support for interactive elements and multi-frame sequences. It operates on geometric primitives (points, lines, grids), view transformations

This module defines 2D and 3D point structures with support for coordinate creation, access, and vector arithmetic. It works with floating-point Cartesian coordinates to enable precise graphical operations in both 2D and 3D space. Concrete use cases include defining plot markers, handling mouse input, performing geometric transformations, and supporting OpenGL rendering pipelines.

The module provides functions for creating and rendering 2D and 3D plots, including parametric curves, surfaces, and annotated visualizations with support for interactive elements and multi-frame sequences. It works with geometric primitives such as points, lines, and grids, along with view transformations to manipulate the scene. Concrete use cases include visualizing mathematical functions, animations for dynamic data, and generating high-quality vector output for publications.
